text.p: Microsoft Corp plans to release a stand-alone version of Outlook 97, a personal information manager bundled with its Office 97 suite of desktop applications, an executive said Tuesday.
The stand-alone product is likely to be available from retailers in March and will sell for about $100, product manager Lani Ota said in an interview.
She said the product would compete against existing personal information managers such as ACT! from Symantec Corp as well as electronic mail clients like Eudora Pro.

The stand-alone version of Outlook will be compatible with standard Internet mail programs as well as the Microsoft Network and CompuServe Corp online services, Ota said. She said Microsoft is testing a driver that would make the software compatible with America Online Inc's mail system.
The product requires Microsoft's Windows 95 or Windows NT operating system, at least eight megabytes of memory and about 30 megabytes of hard-drive space.
Outlook also is being bundled with all versions of Office and is being offered as an option with Microsoft's upcoming Exchange Server version 5.0 electronic mail system.
Microsoft also announced the availability of "add-ons" for Outlook that can be downloaded free over the Internet, including a wizard that allows users to set up e-mail filters.
Ota said Microsoft plans to offer many such add-ons to Outlook users over its World Wide Web site.
